One thing people may not realize is that although I originally wrote
my version of NEAT in C++ for Linux, it can be compiled in Windows
(sacrificing the visualization routines).  In fact, Darren Izzard has
done this, and his explanation is posted in the NEAT FAQ under the
question, "How do I compile your Linux version of NEAT in such and
such operating system?"  The FAQs are on the NEAT Users page: 

http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/kstanley/neat.html

Also, I expanded the introduction on the Users Page to give more
information on how to choose the best implementation of NEAT for your
purposes.

I think one thing that NEAT could really use is a nice experimental
control interface.  Ugo's JNEAT is currently the only version that has
something like this, where you can change parameters and run
experiments and so forth from the same GUI.  Mattias Fagerlund has
some great visualization routines in his Delphi NEAT experiments, as
does Mat Buckland in Windows NEAT.  My own version of NEAT can create
species visualizations, but experimental control comes from parameter
files and through GUILE commands.  I can imagine some master GUI 
interface that kind of combines the ideas from all these variants that
would be extremely useful for running experiments.
It would be cool to hear about anything like this that people have
worked on or thought about.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Chris Christenson <cc57@t...> wrote:
> Hello,
> 
> I plan to use the Windows C++ version.
> 
> C++ because that is the language I am best at, and since I plan to alter
> the code a little that seemed the best plan.
> 
> Windows because I like XP.
> 
> -Chris C
>

> Master's thesis...which implementation do you plan to

> 
> There are now multiple implementations of NEAT
> available in different languages, and as I mentioned
> in my introduction, Philip and I are nearly finished
> with a Java implementation, which we plan to
> open-source.
> 
> Those of you who have implemented your own version of
> NEAT...why did you choose the particular language or
> platform that you did?  
> 
> Derek
